{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3559339,"name":"Mike Stitt","username":"stittrm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/stittrm/{size}/175198_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-17T16:17:20.854Z","cooked":"

We’re looking for suggestions for an elevator latch that allows the elevator to start fully down once at the start of the match, but then once the elevator goes up, to set a new mechanical bottom for the elevator.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-03-17T16:17:20.854Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":237,"readers_count":236,"score":87.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":495904,"topic_slug":"looking-for-suggestions-for-an-elevator-latch","display_username":"Mike Stitt","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54037,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/looking-for-suggestions-for-an-elevator-latch/495904/1","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3559344,"name":"Jake Potter","username":"Ninja_Bait","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ninja_bait/{size}/122409_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-17T16:21:40.778Z","cooked":"

Any reason it can’t be limited by software only?

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-03-17T16:21:40.778Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":234,"readers_count":233,"score":51.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":495904,"topic_slug":"looking-for-suggestions-for-an-elevator-latch","display_username":"Jake Potter","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":14418,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1554 Mentor, 694 Alum, LRI, FIRST Long Island RPC"},"post_url":"/t/looking-for-suggestions-for-an-elevator-latch/495904/2","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3559356,"name":"Mike Stitt","username":"stittrm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/stittrm/{size}/175198_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-17T16:30:45.389Z","cooked":"

Good question! Our robot design is based upon the Rust Hounds RI3D. RustHOUNDS Ri3D 2025

The elevator is continuously rigged. The “pen” that holds the coral is on the first moving stage. The moving Arm and End Effector “plunger” that captures the coral is on the second moving stage. The plunging action of the Arm pointing straight down and elevator plunging the second stage strait down into first stage does not happen until the first stage has gone fully down (because of the continuous rigging).

By latching the bottom of the first stage higher on the elevator, we can reduce our elevator motion that is required to plunge, reducing our cycle time.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-03-17T16:30:45.389Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":229,"readers_count":228,"score":75.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":495904,"topic_slug":"looking-for-suggestions-for-an-elevator-latch","display_username":"Mike Stitt","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/rusthounds-ri3d-2025/477760","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"RustHOUNDS Ri3D 2025","clicks":5}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":14418,"username":"Ninja_Bait","name":"Jake Potter","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ninja_bait/{size}/122409_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54037,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/looking-for-suggestions-for-an-elevator-latch/495904/3","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3559366,"name":"Jake Potter","username":"Ninja_Bait","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ninja_bait/{size}/122409_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-17T16:41:51.387Z","cooked":"

will you still need the first moving stage to return to the true bottom of the elevator to receive coral? Or did you change where the funnel leads?

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-03-17T16:41:51.387Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":181,"readers_count":180,"score":41.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":495904,"topic_slug":"looking-for-suggestions-for-an-elevator-latch","display_username":"Jake Potter","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":54037,"username":"stittrm","name":"Mike Stitt","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/stittrm/{size}/175198_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":14418,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1554 Mentor, 694 Alum, LRI, FIRST Long Island RPC"},"post_url":"/t/looking-for-suggestions-for-an-elevator-latch/495904/4","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3559369,"name":"RockRGI","username":"RockRGI","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rockrgi/{size}/251644_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-17T16:43:54.113Z","cooked":"

you could possibly put a limit switch on the stationary support of the elevator and have a pin or something attached to the coral stage that triggers it the first time it goes by and zeros out the lower to that height in the software. Then when you return down, it will see that level as your software end stop.

Just a quick thought as I read your post.

If you are are wanting a physical stop, you could possibly use a spring loaded pin of some sort that pops out on both sides as your coral section lifts past it on its first move. It would have to be reset in the pits between matches.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-03-17T16:43:54.113Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":171,"readers_count":170,"score":39.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":495904,"topic_slug":"looking-for-suggestions-for-an-elevator-latch","display_username":"RockRGI","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":54037,"username":"stittrm","name":"Mike Stitt","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/stittrm/{size}/175198_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":27915,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/looking-for-suggestions-for-an-elevator-latch/495904/5","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3559371,"name":"Mike Stitt","username":"stittrm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/stittrm/{size}/175198_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-17T16:44:48.135Z","cooked":"

No, we only need to be at the bottom in the starting configuration. Our funnel feeds much higher on the elevator than the Rust Hounds design, reducing the energy in the coral has when it hits the pen.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-03-17T16:44:48.135Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":144,"readers_count":143,"score":28.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":495904,"topic_slug":"looking-for-suggestions-for-an-elevator-latch","display_username":"Mike Stitt","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":14418,"username":"Ninja_Bait","name":"Jake Potter","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ninja_bait/{size}/122409_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54037,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/looking-for-suggestions-for-an-elevator-latch/495904/6","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3559375,"name":"Mike Stitt","username":"stittrm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/stittrm/{size}/175198_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-17T16:48:18.545Z","cooked":"

Yes, an approach to a spring loaded pin or foot that can attach to the outer frame of an elevator and be mechanically stiff enough to be a new bottom stop for the first elevator stage is what we’re looking for.

In the pits, we would raise the elevator a bit, depress the pin/foot, and lower the first stage to the true bottom.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-03-17T16:49:06.362Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":132,"readers_count":131,"score":41.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":495904,"topic_slug":"looking-for-suggestions-for-an-elevator-latch","display_username":"Mike Stitt","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":27915,"username":"RockRGI","name":"RockRGI","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rockrgi/{size}/251644_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54037,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/looking-for-suggestions-for-an-elevator-latch/495904/7","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3559392,"name":"Jake Potter","username":"Ninja_Bait","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ninja_bait/{size}/122409_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-17T17:00:53.003Z","cooked":"

Can you screw something like this right into the side rail? Innovative Components Pull Knob, 1/2" Tip Dia., 0.560"L, Pull Knob GI1/2S2.25-BPL5 | Zoro

The first stage can compress the pin out of the way until you move high enough for it to release and then act as a mechanical stop.

Without seeing your robot it will be hard to design something for you. Are you using pneumatics on your robot? How much higher do you need the new bottom to be?

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-03-17T17:01:09.153Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":119,"readers_count":118,"score":28.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":495904,"topic_slug":"looking-for-suggestions-for-an-elevator-latch","display_username":"RockRGI","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":54037,"username":"stittrm","name":"Mike Stitt","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/stittrm/{size}/175198_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":27915,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/looking-for-suggestions-for-an-elevator-latch/495904/9","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3559401,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-17T17:05:46.238Z","cooked":"

Maybe a strip (or two) of 1/4" polycarb that is flexed out of the way when you are starting, and pops into the right place to be the stop the first time your elevator goes up? It probably doesn’t need to go very far in to work on an elevator. There’s going to be a limit to the buckling strength of it, but, its simple…

We are using a flexing polycarb latch on our retractable funnel, which is why I was thinking about it

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-03-17T17:05:46.238Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":117,"readers_count":116,"score":53.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":495904,"topic_slug":"looking-for-suggestions-for-an-elevator-latch","display_username":"Rod","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46443,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/looking-for-suggestions-for-an-elevator-latch/495904/10","reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3559411,"name":"waialua3:59","username":"waialua359","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/waialua359/{size}/676_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-17T17:10:13.903Z","cooked":"

Nomads 6995 has a nice way to do it using a WCP brake without pneumatics, but instead on a folding arm.

At first glance the “simplest” method might be to add a hinged piece to the lower support of the first stage such that as you lift the elevator up, the spacer drops into place effectively moving your physical end stop. No motors or pneumatics required and doesn’t weigh much.

This was my first thought as well. For some reference, 254 did something similar in 2023 but just in the opposite direction to start higher in order to place the preload quicker: Team 254 Presents: 2023 BREAKDOWN - Technical Binder, Code, Q&A - #39 by Torrance

In your case, this could just be a mechanism that snaps into the path of the carriage rather than out of it.
